attributes.title: Allometric Scaling and Volumetric  Neuroanatomical Markers

q1.value: Neuroanatomical Norms and Markers in the UKBiobank

q2.value: Camille Williams, Hugo Peyre, Franck Ramus

q3.value:
Although all humans share a common brain structure and organization, they also vary enormously in terms of the size and shape of their brain and of its subcomponents. 

To this day, the number of sufficiently powered studies appropriately examining normative neuroanatomical differences remains small and the extent to which these variations depend on factors typically reported to influence cerebral differences, such as age, and sex, is not well established. Even fewer studies have considered brain allometry (e.g. the non-linear scaling relationship between local and total brain volumes). Yet recent findings suggest that (i) the methods of adjustment for total brain volumes  applied when examining local volumetric group (e.g. sex, or ASD) differences contribute to the variability of findings on volumetric group differences (e.g. Reardon et al., 2016; Sanchis-Segura et al., 2019) and that (ii) adjusting for total brain volume with allometric scaling provides a more accurate description of the relationship between local and total brain volumes, since it follows a power function rather than a linear one (Finaly et al., 2001; Liu et al., 2014). To our knowledge, we propose the first large-scale study (N ~ 40 000) to examine brain volumes and volumetric asymmetries while adjusting for individual differences in total brain volume with allometric scaling. 

The primary goal of the present study will be to establish neuroanatomical population norms (in the UKBiobank), taking into account brain allometry, sex, and age effects. Individual neuroanatomical markers will be derived from these norms, with the aim of studying their relationship with cognitive phenotypes (described in a later preregistration). 

Finlay, B. L., Darlington, R. B., & Nicastro, N. (2001). Developmental structure in brain evolution. The Behavioral and Brain Sciences, 24(2), 263–278; discussion 278-308. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0140525X01003958

Liu, D., Johnson, H. J., Long, J. D., Magnotta, V. A., & Paulsen, J. S. (2014). The power-proportion method for intracranial volume correction in volumetric imaging analysis. Frontiers in Neuroscience, 8. https://doi.org/10.3389/fnins.2014.00356

Reardon, P. K., Clasen, L., Giedd, J. N., Blumenthal, J., Lerch, J. P., Chakravarty, M. M., & Raznahan, A. (2016). An Allometric Analysis of Sex and Sex Chromosome Dosage Effects on Subcortical Anatomy in Humans. The Journal of Neuroscience: The Official Journal of the Society for Neuroscience, 36(8), 2438–2448. https://doi.org/10.1523/JNEUROSCI.3195-15.2016

Sanchis-Segura, C., Ibañez-Gual, M. V., Adrián-Ventura, J., Aguirre, N., Gómez-Cruz, Á. J., Avila, C., & Forn, C. (2019). Sex differences in gray matter volume: How many and how large are they really? Biology of Sex Differences, 10(1), 32. https://doi.org/10.1186/s13293-019-0245-7

q4.value: The primary goal of the study is descriptive. Nevertheless, based on previous studies, we hypothesize that grey matter volumes, surface area, and cortical thickness will scale allometrically to total brain volume, total surface area, and mean cortical thickness, respectively. Moreover, we hypothesize that these cerebral measures will vary with age and sex.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We will analyze previously collected data from the UKBiobank to conduct our descriptive study. 
To achieve normative neuroanatomical markers we will include all participants, including those with medical conditions. However, participants with missing brain imaging data will not be included in the study.  

We will consider all the local brain measures (volumes, surface area, and cortical thickness) available in the UKBiobank as dependent variables, and sex, age (linear and quadratic), mean cortical thickness (or total cortical volume), total surface area, and total brain volume as predictors, in multiple regression analyses.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The data was downloaded and opened by C. Williams, who also ran descriptive statistics on a subset of the data (~ 20 000 individuals available at the time).

question.value:
The UKBiobank is a large database created for the study of health and well-being which includes neurimaging, genetic, cognitive and behavioral measures (Sudlow et al., 2015). 
UKBiobank Image acquisition protocols, processing pipeline, and database variables for brain imaging can be found here: https://biobank.ctsu.ox.ac.uk/crystal/crystal/docs/brain_mri.pdf. The MRI data was acquired with the same software and hardware across three sites. 

Sudlow, C., Gallacher, J., Allen, N., Beral, V., Burton, P., Danesh, J., … Collins, R. (2015). UK Biobank: An Open Access Resource for Identifying the Causes of a Wide Range of Complex Diseases of Middle and Old Age. PLOS Medicine, 12(3), e1001779. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pmed.1001779

q13.value: We will use all available brain MRI data form the UKBiobank. Currently ~ 45 000 individuals have brain MRI scans and subcortical and cortical imaging data available. If more data is available while we are establishing the neuroanatomical markers, we will attempt to include them in our sample.

q14.value: We will use all of the currently available brain MRI data from the UKBiobank.

question.value:
Dependent variables will be all left and right local measures of volume, surface area and cortical thickness provided by the UKBiobank. 

We will use the amygdala (N = 18), hippocampus (N = 38), thalamus (N = 50) and brainstem (N = 4) subsegmentations available in the UKBiobank. Segmentations for the caudate, putamen, pallidum, and accumbens will be obtained from the FIRST subcortical (N = 8). We will take the local cortical surface area (N = 148), mean thickness (N = 148), and volumes (N = 148) from the Freesurfer a2009s segmentations. Cerebellar regions will be extracted from the FAST (N = 28) segmentation and ventricle volumes will be taken from the Freesurfer ASEG (N = 8) segmentations.

When choices between different types of segmentation are available, we will take the smallest segmentations available (e.g. FreeSurfer Tools Subsegmentations; FIRST subcortical segmentations) to obtain a more fine grain analysis.

Analyses will be conducted in three steps with R studio. Code will be posted on git hub to facilitate replication. All variables will be standardized (centered and divided by 1 SD).

Step 1 - Identify global markers across individuals. 

We will conduct preliminary global analyses to evaluate how Total Surface Area (TSA) and Mean Cortical Thickness (MCT) vary with Total Brain Volume (TBV), age, age2, and sex. The following equation (i) will be applied with TSA and MCT as dependent variables (DV). 

(i)	Log10(DV) = Intercept 
                + β1 (Log10(TBV)) 
         	+ β2 (Age) 
                + β3 (Sex) 
                + β4 (Age2)
                + β5 (Log10(TBV) x Sex)
                + β6 (Log10(TBV) x Age) 
                + β7 (Log10(TBV) x Age2) 
                + β8 (Age x Sex) 
                + β9 (Age2 x Sex) 
                + β10 (Log10(TBV) x Age x Sex ) 
                + β11 (Log10(TBV) x Age2 x Sex ) 
                + Error

Step 2 - We will extract the residuals for each examined DV. An individual’s residual value for a given DV will reflect that individual’s  deviance from the allometric norm, given his/her age, sex, and total cerebral measure, and will therefore constitute a new neuroanatomical marker.

Step 3 - Identify local markers across individuals. 
We will conduct local analyses to evaluate how local volumes, surface areas, and cortical thickness vary with TBV, age, age2, and sex. The following equation (ii) will be applied with local volume, surface areas, or cortical thickness as DVs (e.g. Area of S-temporal-transverse Left Hemisphere). When the DV is a volume the Total Cerebral Measure will be TBV. When the DV is a surface area the Total Cerebral Measure will be TSA and when the DV is a mean cortical thickness the Total Cerebral Measure will be MCT. 

(ii)	Log10(DV) = Intercept 
                + β1 (Log10(Total Cerebral Measure)) 
         	+ β2 (Age) 
                + β3 (Sex) 
                + β4 (Age2)
                + β5 (Log10(Total Cerebral Measure) x Sex)
                + β6 (Log10(Total Cerebral Measure) x Age) 
                + β7 (Log10(Total Cerebral Measure) x Age2) 
                + β8 (Age x Sex) 
                + β9 (Age2 x Sex) 
                + β10 (Log10(Total Cerebral Measure) x Age x Sex ) 
                + β11 (Log10(Total Cerebral Measure) x Age2 x Sex ) 
                + Error

Step 4 - We will extract the residuals for each examined local volume, area, or thickness. An individual’s residual value for a given volumetric(/thickness/surface) will reflect that individual’s  deviance from the allometric norm, given his/her age, sex, and total cerebral measure, and will therefore constitute a new neuroanatomical marker.

Step 5 – From the person-level local neuroanatomical markers, we will create a person-level global allometric marker with equation (iii). This will correspond to a person’s global cerebral deviance from the norm in terms of allometric scaling. 

(iii)	global allometric marker = squareroot(∑(Person-Level neuroanatomical Markers)2)

Step 6 - We will replicate previous analyses that considered brain allometry when examining sex differences in the literature. When available in the UKBiobank, we will use the same segmentations (e..g instead of using the amygdala volume from the subsegmentation algorithms we will also use the FIRST segmentations if the FIRST segmentation was used in the study we aim to replicate).   

Specifically, we will attempt to replicate the following findings: 

1. Right and left lobar (frontal, occipital, limbic, parietal, temporal, and cerebellum) sex differences reported by Peyre et al., 2020 (Figure 1. Right and left cerebellum grey matter : boys greater than girls; right (d = -0.2) and left frontal grey matter : girls greater than boys (d = 0.08-0.1)).

 2. A greater pallidal volume in males and relative caudate head expansion and ventral striatum contraction in females reported by Reardon and colleagues (2016). 

3. Relative expansion of total cerebellum, flocculus, and Crus II-lobule VIIIB volumes in males and X-specific contraction of Crus II-lobule VIIIB by Mankiw et al., 2017 (Figure 6).

4. Sex differences reported by Sanchis-Segura et al., 2019 in Figure 2 when adjusting for allometry with the power-corrected proportion method was proposed by Liu et al. (2014) were the following (Figure 2): 
- Left, female greater than male : Frontal superior, superior orbital, mid, med orbital, occipital med, postcentral, parietal inf, cerebellum X; male greater than female cerebellum crus I, pallidum, putamen, amygdala. 
- Right, female greater than male: Frontal superior orbital, frontal med orbital occipital superior, mid, and parietal inferior; male grater than female: temporal pole mid, pallidum, putamen, amygdala, and lingual. We will aim to replicate these findings using the linear allometric adjustment.

q20.value:
To examine allometric scaling, we will apply the log10 transformation to all volumetric, cortical thickness, and surface area measures.

We will also standardize (center with the mean and divide by one SD) all continuous variables since our variables are on different scales and to report standardize betas as effect sizes. Thus , we will be examining the main effect of TBV, for instance, when the other variables are at their mean value and not 0. 

Considering that we have no specific hypotheses on categorical predictors (i.e. sex), categorical variables will be coded -.5 and .5 so that we can obtain the slope (main effect) of a variable (e.g. age) across sexes (Male = -.5 and Female = .5) rather than examining it for sex = 0 (where Male = 0 and Female = 1).

q22.value:
All participants without cerebral data will be excluded from the analyses. 
Outliers will be maintained in this study considering the size of our sample size. However, individuals with a segmentation of 0 will be removed from the analyses of that segmentation. 
Based on the recommendations from the UKBiobank Imaging Protocols (https://biobank.ctsu.ox.ac.uk/crystal/crystal/docs/brain_mri.pdf),  will only analyze cortical thickness and surface area data from individuals where T2-FLAIR was used in addition to T1 to run FreeSurfer (http://biobank.ndph.ox.ac.uk/showcase/field.cgi?id=26500).

q23.value:
When the age at the time of the imaging visit (second visit) is missing we will use the age of the participant from another visit and the date of their imaging visit to estimate age. 

There are two measures of sex: reported sex and genetic sex. We will use reported sex to infer sex when genetic sex is not available. Participants with inconsistencies between sex and genetic sex will be removed. We will provide the % concordance between genetic and reported sex to estimate the % of individuals whose sex may be wrongly reported because they only have reported and not genetic sex data.

attributes.title: Amendments
attributes.description: Amendments to OSF Preregistration for Comparing Simulations & Vignettes within Crime Studies

q2.value: Miko M. Wilford, Kelly T. Sutherland, Joseph Gonzales

q3.value:
The vast majority of criminal convictions in the United States are secured via guilty pleas. Yet, the process of pleading has received relatively little research attention compared to other psycho-legal topics. It is possible that the dearth of plea research is due, at least in part, to limitations in the current methods of experimentally studying pleas: vignettes and high-stakes deception studies.

The proposed research will propose an alternative methodological approach to plea studies, the computer simulation. To the researchers’ knowledge, no current study exists that directly compares outcomes from a plea computer simulation with a plea vignette. .

q4.value:
(1) Participants will report higher levels of engagement and immersion with the simulation versus the vignette.
(2) Participants will demonstrate greater levels of identification with their customized avatar than with the character in the vignette.
(3) Participants will plead guilty more when guilty than when innocent in both the simulation and vignette.
(4) Participants will falsely plead guilty at a higher rate in the simulation condition versus the vignette condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study is a 2 (study method: simulation or vignette) x 2 (guilt status: innocent or guilty) x 2 (plea & trial sentence: 6 months probation, 12 months jail or 12 months probation, 24 months in jail) mixed-design.  Most measures will be compared within participants as all will be randomly assigned to experience both the study methods, as well as both the plea discount & trial penalty combinations.  The order of these conditions will be counterbalanced. Guilt status will be randomly assigned for each scenario (so participants could be innocent for both scenarios, guilty for both scenarios, or innocent for one and guilty for another).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from Prolific Academic, accessing the study on Qualtrics. Participants must have a prior HIT completion rate of 95%, must reside in the United States, must access the study from a desktop or laptop computer, must use an approved browser, and must customize their avatar prior to the simulation. Participants will be paid $4.00 for participation in the full study, as we expect that it will take ~35 minutes. There is a CAPTCHA immediately following the informed consent, which aims to eliminate rudimentary bots. Additionally, there are three embedded attention checks to identify participants who are not fully reading the questions. There are also six manipulation checks. Participants who do not accurately answer two of the three attention checks will not be compensated for completion of the study (and their data will not be included).  Also, we will exclude data from participants who do not accurately answer at least two of the three manipulation checks correctly for each scenario.

q13.value: It is necessary to obtain a minimum sample size of 210 participants. Due to attrition rates, it will be necessary to recruit 250 participants.

q14.value: A power analysis was conducted for a two-tailed, t-test of two dependent means for an effect size of 0.25, power of 0.95, and alpha of 0.05.

question.value:
Guilt status (innocent or guilty) will be randomly assigned
Plea & trial sentence will be randomly assigned (6 months probation, 12 months jail OR 12 months probation, 24 months jail)
Order of study method (vignette or simulation) will be randomly assigned
Order of scenario (hit-and-run or theft) will be randomly assigned

Prior to beginning the study, we will collect:
-	Demographics

After both the vignette and simulation, we will measure:
-	Factual and subjective guilt 
-	Factual and subjective probability of conviction 
-	Factual and subjective assessments of the plea and trial penalty 
-	Counterfactuals (“If the plea deal…., would you…?”) 

At the very end of the study, we will collect:
- Comparisons of simulation and vignette	
- Additional demographics
- Prior experience with hit-and-runs and thefts
- Gaming frequency
N/A

The data analysis plan will test the individual hypotheses as follows:
(1) Mean % for questions comparing immersion/engagement with the simulations vs. vignette
(2) Mean % for questions comparing identification with the avatar vs. character
(3) t-test comparing plea outcomes as a function of guilt status
(4) t-test comparing plea outcomes as a function of simulation vs. vignette

Additionally, exploratory analyses may include: modeling predictive analyses, correlational tests, demographic summaries of variables, and additional computations of inferential statistics.

q21.value: We will be using two-tailed tests with a p-value of 0.05.  If needed, correctional factors will be used when testing multiple hypotheses.

q22.value: Participants will need to pass 2/3 of the manipulation checks for each scenario for their data to be included in the analysis. For compensation purposes, participants will need to pass 2/3 of the attention checks.

registration_responses.q3:
The vast majority of criminal convictions in the United States are secured via guilty pleas. Yet, the process of pleading has received relatively little research attention compared to other psycho-legal topics. It is possible that the dearth of plea research is due, at least in part, to limitations in the current methods of experimentally studying pleas: vignettes and high-stakes deception studies.

The proposed research will propose an alternative methodological approach to plea studies, the computer simulation. To the researchers’ knowledge, no current study exists that directly compares outcomes from a plea computer simulation with a plea vignette. .
registration_responses.q4:
(1) Participants will report higher levels of engagement and immersion with the simulation versus the vignette.
(2) Participants will demonstrate greater levels of identification with their customized avatar than with the character in the vignette.
(3) Participants will plead guilty more when guilty than when innocent in both the simulation and vignette.
(4) Participants will falsely plead guilty at a higher rate in the simulation condition versus the vignette condition.

The order of these conditions will be counterbalanced. attributes.title: Replikation Experiment 3 Capacity Limitations of Dishonesty

q1.value: Replikation der Studie “Capacity Limitations of Dishonesty”, Experiment 3 von Anna Foerster, Robert Wirth, Frauke L. Berghoefer, Wilfried Kunde und Roland Pfister

q3.value:
Arbeitstitel: Replikation des 3. Experimentes der Studie Foerster, A., Wirth, R., Berghoefer, F. L., Kunde, W., & Pfister, R. (2019). Capacity limitations of dishonesty. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General, 148(6), 943–961. 
Die zu replizierende Studie stellt für ihr Experiment ein Pool von 72 Fragen über alltägliche Tätigkeiten vor, d.h. die Probanden beantworten, ob sie diese Tätigkeiten am Tag des Experiments bereits durchführten. Die gleiche Fragensammlung wird auch für unsere Replikationsstudie verwendet. 
Dabei werden den Versuchspersonen zunächst zufällig so lange Fragen aus diesem Pool gestellt, bis sie 10 Fragen ehrlich bejahen und 10 Fragen ehrlich verneinen können. Diese 20 Fragen werden später für die (Un-)Ehrlich-Aufgaben verwendet. Dabei sitzen die Versuchspersonen vor einem Bildschirm, der ihnen diese Fragen anzeigt, wobei ihnen verschiedene Schriftfarben signalisieren, ob sie ehrlich oder unehrlich auf die gestellten Fragen antworten sollen. Die Antwort erfolgt über das Drücken von Tasten mit der linken Hand auf einer deutschen Standard-QWERTZ-Tastatur. Die Tasten S und D werden zur Beantwortung der (Un-)Ehrlich-Aufgabe benutzt, wobei die Zuordnung von Ja und Nein zu den jeweiligen Tasten zwischen den Probanden ausbalanciert wird. 
Mit einer festgelegten zeitlichen Verzögerung nach dem Erscheinden der Frage wird den Probanden für 100 ms ein Ton unabhängig von der (Nicht-) Beantwortung der Frage präsentiert. Dieser kann entweder hoch (800 Hz) oder niedrig (300 Hz) sein. Der Ton soll von der Versuchsperson klassifiziert werden. Die Tasten K und L werden zur Beantwortung der Tonaufgabe benutzt, hier wird ebenfalls die Tastenzuordnung zwischen den Probanden ausbalanciert. Die bereits erwähnte zeitliche Verzögerung der Tonpräsentation nach Erscheinen der Frage nennt man SOA (stimulus onset asynchrony). Dieses gestaltet sich kurz (150 ms) oder lang (1500 ms). Ab der Tonpräsenation haben die Versuchspersonen zur Beantwortung der Aufgabe 4000 ms Zeit. 
Insgesamt gibt es 160 individuelle trial-Kombinationen in einem Block. Jeder Proband wird drei dieser Blöcke durchlaufen mit einer selbstgewählten Pause nach jedem 40. trial. 
Dabei werden die Reaktionszeiten und die Genauigkeit bei der (un-)ehrlichen Antwort auf die Fragen und bei der Identifizierung des Tons gemessen.

q4.value:
Unehrliche Antworten gehören zu der zentralen aber kapazitäts-limitierten Phase der Informationsverarbeitung. Deshalb ist die gleichzeitige oder unmittelbar folgende Bearbeitung anderer Aufgaben erschwert. 

Manipulationscheck: Es wird davon ausgegangen, dass die Reaktionszeiten und die Fehlerrate bei unehrlichen Antworten größer sind als bei ehrlichen Antworten wegen der psychologischen Refraktärperiode. Zusätzlich besteht die Annahme, dass die Reaktionszeiten und die Fehlerrate bei kurzem SOA immer größer sind als bei langem SOA, da zentrale Prozesse nicht parallel ablaufen können. 

Interaktion: Bei einem langen SOA sollte sicher ein geringer Effekt der Absicht (ehrlich vs. unehrlich) auf die Reaktionszeiten und Fehlerraten zeigen, da postzentrale Prozesse parallel zu anderen Prozessen ablaufen können (die zentrale Verarbeitung sollte in diesem Fall bereits abgeschlossen sein).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Alle Bedingungen werden within subject manipuliert. Jedem Probanden werden 20 Ja/Nein-Fragen zugeordnet, davon 10 getätigte und 10 nicht getätigte Aktivitäten x 2 Absichten (ehrlich vs. unehrlich) x 2 SOA (kurz vs. lang) x 2 Ton (tief vs. hoch).

q9.value: Es erfolgt eine randomisierte Verteilung der Alltagsfragen aus dem 72-Fragenpool.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Es wurden noch keine Daten für diese Studie erhoben.

question.value: Die Daten werden im Rahmen des Moduls „Experimentalpsychologisches Praktikum“ in der Technischen Universität Dresden erhoben, wobei Studierende (vor allem des 3.Semesters des Bachelorstudienganges Psychologie) die Probanden sein werden. Studierende aus anderen Seminar-Gruppen werden als Probanden zugeordnet und an dem Experiment teilnehmen, welches ungefähr eine Stunde dauert. Sie erhalten dafür keine Vergütung. Die Altersspanne liegt zwischen 18 und 50 Jahren.

q13.value: Es werden ca. 40 Probanden an dieser Replikationsstudie teilnehmen.

q14.value: Die Anzahl der Probanden ist wegen organisatorischer Gründe vorgegeben.

question.value:
SOA: Manipuliert wird der zeitliche Abstand zwischen Erscheinen der Frage und dem Beginn des Tons  – definiert als SOA. Der Ton wird entweder nach einer kurzen zeitlichen Verzögerung (kurzes SOA von 150 ms) oder mit einer längeren zeitlichen Verzögerung (langes SOA von 1500 ms) abgespielt. 

Absicht: Zusätzlich wird manipuliert, ob die Versuchspersonen auf die ihnen gestellte Frage ehrlich oder unehrlich antworten sollen. Dies wird den Versuchspersonen über die Schriftfarbe der auf dem Bildschirm angezeigten Frage vermittelt. 

Tonhöhe: Außerdem wird die Höhe des Tons, der nach der (Un-)ehrlich-Aufgabe gespielt und von den Versuchspersonen als entweder hoch oder niedrig eingeschätzt werden soll, manipuliert. Dabei entspricht ein niedriger Ton einer Höhe von 300 Hz und der hohe Ton einer Höhe von 800 Hz. Beide Töne werden für jeweils 100 ms gespielt.

Fragebögen: Bevor das Computerexperiment startet, füllen die Probanden einen Fragebogen zu demografischen Angaben (Alter, Geschlecht, Händigkeit etc.) und den Mehrdimensionalen Befindlichkeitsfragebogen (MDBF) aus. Der MDBF wird erneut im Anschluss an das Computerexperiment erhoben.

Computerexperiment: Die beiden abhängigen Variablen sind die Reaktionszeiten bei der (un-)ehrlichen Antwort auf die Fragen und bei der Identifizierung des Tons als hoch oder niedrig und die Fehlerraten (für Tonaufgabe und Fragen), welche über Tastendruck auf einer deutschen Standard-Computertastatur erfasst werden.

Es werden 2x2 repeated-measures ANOVAs für Reaktionszeit und Fehlerrate mit den within-Factors SOA (kurz vs. lang) und Absicht (ehrlich vs. unehrlich) berechnet, diese erfolgen für jede Aufgabe seperat. 

Follow-up: Falls die ANOVA signifikante Interaktionseffekte aufzeigt, werden zweiseitige t-Tests für abhängige Stichproben berechnet.

q21.value: Das Signifikanzniveau wird auf 5 Prozent festgesetzt. Eventuell werden wir eine Bonferroni-Korrektur vornehmen.

q22.value:
Die Daten aus den Übungsblocks sowie die trials nach einer selbstgewählten Pause werden ausgeschlossen. Wenn die Versuchsperson angibt eine falsche Antwort bei den Ja/Nein Fragen getätigt zu haben, werden auch die Daten dieser Person ausgeschlossen. Das Gleiche gilt für Versuchspersonen mit >= 50% commission errors (commission error: linke Antwort bei korrekter rechter Antwort oder umgekehrt). Die Daten eines trials, welcher auf einen inkorrekten trial folgt, werden ebenfalls ausgeschlossen. 

Fehlerrate: Fehlende Antworten werden ausgeschlossen bei der Analyse der Fehlerrate bei der (Un-)ehrlich-Aufgabe. Die Fehlerrate wird folgendermaßen berechnet: Anzahl der commission error/ [Anzahl der commission error + Anzahl der korrekten Antworten]. 

Reaktionszeiten: Bei der Analyse der Reaktionszeiten werden alle Fehler ausgeschlossen. Ebenso werden Reaktionszeiten von > 4000 ms ab Erscheinen des Tons nicht berücksichtigt. Für die Analyse der Reaktionszeiten beider Aufgaben werden  Reaktionszeiten über 2,5x Standardabweichungen des korrespondierenden Zellenmittelwerts ausgeschlossen.

q23.value: Beim Fragebogen werden fehlende Informationen und beim Computerexperiment werden fehelende trials nicht berücksichtigt.

q24.value: Hängen eventuelle Veränderungen der Stimmung (MDBF) mit dem Effekt zusammen?

q25.value:
Authorship: Studierende der Technischen Universität Dresden, die Teilnehmer der Seminargruppe “Experimentalpsychologisches Praktikum – Allgemeine Psychologie“ unter Dipl.-Psych Marcus Möschl sind. 

Research Questions: Die Studie betrachtet die kognitiven Auswirkungen von Unehrlichkeit auf die Phasen der Informationsverarbeitung. Im Experiment 3 wird untersucht, ob sich ehrliche und unehrliche Antworten bereits in zentralen und postzentralen Verarbeitungsphasen unterscheiden.

Fehlerrate: Fehlende Antworten werden ausgeschlossen bei der Analyse der Fehlerrate bei der (Un-)ehrlich-Aufgabe. Die Fehlerrate wird folgendermaßen berechnet: Anzahl der commission error/ [Anzahl der commission error + Anzahl der korrekten Antworten]. 

Reaktionszeiten: Bei der Analyse der Reaktionszeiten werden alle Fehler ausgeschlossen. Ebenso werden Reaktionszeiten von > 4000 ms ab Erscheinen des Tons nicht berücksichtigt. Für die Analyse der Reaktionszeiten beider Aufgaben werden  Reaktionszeiten über 2,5x Standardabweichungen des korrespondierenden Zellenmittelwerts ausgeschlossen.
registration_responses.q23: Beim Fragebogen werden fehlende Informationen und beim Computerexperiment werden fehelende trials nicht berücksichtigt.
registration_responses.q24: Hängen eventuelle Veränderungen der Stimmung (MDBF) mit dem Effekt zusammen?
registration_responses.q25:
Authorship: Studierende der Technischen Universität Dresden, die Teilnehmer der Seminargruppe “Experimentalpsychologisches Praktikum – Allgemeine Psychologie“ unter Dipl.-Psych Marcus Möschl sind. 

Research Questions: Die Studie betrachtet die kognitiven Auswirkungen von Unehrlichkeit auf die Phasen der Informationsverarbeitung. Im Experiment 3 wird untersucht, ob sich ehrliche und unehrliche Antworten bereits in zentralen und postzentralen Verarbeitungsphasen unterscheiden.
registration_responses.q8.question: Alle Bedingungen werden within subject manipuliert. Jedem Probanden werden 20 Ja/Nein-Fragen zugeordnet, davon 10 getätigte und 10 nicht getätigte Aktivitäten x 2 Absichten (ehrlich vs. unehrlich) x 2 SOA (kurz vs. lang) x 2 Ton (tief vs. hoch).
registration_responses.q12.question: Die Daten werden im Rahmen des Moduls „Experimentalpsychologisches Praktikum“ in der Technischen Universität Dresden erhoben, wobei Studierende (vor allem des 3.Semesters des Bachelorstudienganges Psychologie) die Probanden sein werden. Studierende aus anderen Seminar-Gruppen werden als Probanden zugeordnet und an dem Experiment teilnehmen, welches ungefähr eine Stunde dauert. Sie erhalten dafür keine Vergütung. Die Altersspanne liegt zwischen 18 und 50 Jahren.
registration_responses.q16.question:
SOA: Manipuliert wird der zeitliche Abstand zwischen Erscheinen der Frage und dem Beginn des Tons  – definiert als SOA. Der Ton wird entweder nach einer kurzen zeitlichen Verzögerung (kurzes SOA von 150 ms) oder mit einer längeren zeitlichen Verzögerung (langes SOA von 1500 ms) abgespielt. 

Absicht: Zusätzlich wird manipuliert, ob die Versuchspersonen auf die ihnen gestellte Frage ehrlich oder unehrlich antworten sollen. Dies wird den Versuchspersonen über die Schriftfarbe der auf dem Bildschirm angezeigten Frage vermittelt. 

Tonhöhe: Außerdem wird die Höhe des Tons, der nach der (Un-)ehrlich-Aufgabe gespielt und von den Versuchspersonen als entweder hoch oder niedrig eingeschätzt werden soll, manipuliert. Dabei entspricht ein niedriger Ton einer Höhe von 300 Hz und der hohe Ton einer Höhe von 800 Hz. Beide Töne werden für jeweils 100 ms gespielt.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Fragebögen: Bevor das Computerexperiment startet, füllen die Probanden einen Fragebogen zu demografischen Angaben (Alter, Geschlecht, Händigkeit etc.) und den Mehrdimensionalen Befindlichkeitsfragebogen (MDBF) aus. Der MDBF wird erneut im Anschluss an das Computerexperiment erhoben.

Computerexperiment: Die beiden abhängigen Variablen sind die Reaktionszeiten bei der (un-)ehrlichen Antwort auf die Fragen und bei der Identifizierung des Tons als hoch oder niedrig und die Fehlerraten (für Tonaufgabe und Fragen), welche über Tastendruck auf einer deutschen Standard-Computertastatur erfasst werden.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Es werden 2x2 repeated-measures ANOVAs für Reaktionszeit und Fehlerrate mit den within-Factors SOA (kurz vs. lang) und Absicht (ehrlich vs. unehrlich) berechnet, diese erfolgen für jede Aufgabe seperat. 

Follow-up: Falls die ANOVA signifikante Interaktionseffekte aufzeigt, werden zweiseitige t-Tests für abhängige Stichproben berechnet.

attributes.title: Income Inequality and Counterfeits - Egalitarian Motives

q1.value: effect of income inequality on iPhone Goophone relative ratings

q2.value: S. Wiley Wakeman, Jingshi Liu, Michael I Norton

q3.value: In this study, we test how perceived income inequality affects people's perceptions of a genuine vs. a counterfeit phone.

q4.value: Under high (vs. low) income inequality, consumers are more likely to perceive counterfeit (vs. genuine) products to have greater egalitarian value. The egalitarian value in turn positively affects consumers' attitudes toward counterfeits. The effect of egalitarian value on counterfeit attitudes should be independent of the hedonic, utilitarian, status signaling, and economic values of a counterfeit.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: 2 condition (video: income inequality, neutral) between-subjects design

q9.value: Participants are randomly assigned to one of the 2 (video: income inequality, neutral). In the income inequality condition, they watch a video about wealth inequality in the US. In the neutral video, they watch a video about brain science.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will post the study on MTurk or Prolific. Participants will receive monetary rewards for their participation. Participants who reside in the U.S. are allowed to participate. For MTurk workers, only those with a 95% HIT acceptance rate are eligible to participate. 

Before participants can start the study, they must pass two screening questions to make sure they are not robots. One question requires basic human logic and common sense (e.g., up is to down as left is to ___?) and the other question is a Qualtrics Catcha. We will include an additional screening question, an attention check and a comprehension check (for the video prime) in the study. Participants who fail the screening check will not be able to proceed further with the study. Data from participants who fail either or both checks will be excluded from analyses. 

We will use scripts to exclude MTurk or Prolific workers who have completed the study before, but will also check for redundant MTurk/Prolific IDs and exclude these participants.

q14.value: Based on the results from our previous studies, a cell size of 150 is pre-determined. We will recruit 350 to account for participants who fail the attention check and comprehension check, and hence will be excluded from the analyses.

q15.value: We will collect data until the sample size is met.

question.value: Video prime: participants watch a video either about income inequality in the US, or a neutral video about brain science.

Participants complete measures of the following values for phones: hedonic value, utilitarian value, economic value, social signaling value, and egalitarian value. Additionally we will test for egalitarian value using the dominance and antiegalitarian routes described in Ho et al., (2015, JPSP - The nature of social dominance: see beginning of this wiki for the exact items). For all these measures, the scale end points are: 1 = more representative of the iPhone, 7 = more representative of the Goophone. 

Additional dependent variables: which phone they are more willing to purchase, iphone or goophone.  

Potential covariates and moderators: Demographic variables, e.g., age, gender, income, SES.

All the scale measures with more than one item will be combined into an index by averaging the scores of all items in the scale. Before creating the index, we will first reversed code the items that are phrased reservedly. We will also test the reliability of the scale before creating the index. A chrombach's alpha = .7 is considered acceptable.

Separate ANOVAs on each of the dependent measures will be conducted, using the video prime as a factor as well as simple t-tests when no covariates [or controls] are needed for analysis. 
We will test parallel mediating effect of the different relative perceived values (hedonic value, utilitarian value, economic value, social signaling value, and egalitarian value) on the effect of video prime on purchase intention toward counterfeits.

q20.value: Skewed dependent variables will be log transformed.

q21.value: p= .1 is marginally significant. p = .05 is significant. We will test simple effects of any interactions that are marginally significant.

q22.value: Data from participants who fail the attention check and the comprehension check will be excluded from analyses. Any participants who have already completed studies in this project will be excluded.

q23.value: Participants with incomplete data will be excluded from analyses.

attributes.title: 正性、负性社会语义信息和非社会语义信息加工的异同：行为和ERP研究

q1.value: 正性、负性社会语义信息和非社会语义信息加工的异同：行为和ERP研究

q2.value: 杨亚平, 范鑫芳, 陈庆伟, 计邹慧, 徐强

q3.value:
近期以图片为实验材料的ERP研究操纵了图片刺激的效价和社会性, 一致证明了图片中信息的社会性和效价的加工存在着交互作用。 描述人的词汇是一类非常重要的、特别的社会语义信息, 且关于人的特质描述往往带有评价性, 亦即具有某种效价。因此, 不论是从理论上还是从研究的生态效度上, 都需要将词汇的效价作为重要的自变量进行考察。然而, 以往以描述人的词汇为实验材料探讨社会语义信息加工特异性的ERP研究, 尚未涉及对词汇效价的操纵(e. g., Wang et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2018; White et al., 2009; 杨亚平 等, 2015)。尽管近期也有研究以描述人的词汇为实验材料且操纵了效价, 但此类研究仅考察了社会语义信息加工的神经活动特征, 缺乏与之对比的非社会语义信息(Zhang et al., 2014; Zhao, Chen, Zhou, & Luo, 2018)。尽管对于ERP实验而言上述研究中所选取的描述人的词汇有限(正性、负性和中性的词汇各6个)且研究结果不完全一致, 但这两项研究提供了大脑在早期知觉阶段就可以检测并区分负性社会语义信息的证据。然而, 同样由于缺乏之对比的非社会语义信息, 这一负性词汇的早期知觉优势是否是社会语义信息所特有的还需进一步验证。总之, 关于不同效价的社会语义信息的加工有何特异性这一问题亟需探讨。
为此, 本研究拟结合行为反应时技术和具有高时间分辨率的ERP技术, 借鉴Mitchell等人(2002)的研究, 操纵了社会语义信息和与之对比的非社会语义信息, 即以描述人的词汇和描述无生命物体的词汇为研究对象, 采用启动范式——以人名和物名为启动刺激, 以描述人的词汇(如: 大度、懒惰)和描述物的词汇(如: 可口、破旧)为靶子刺激。所不同的是, 本研究操纵了词汇的效价并采用靶子词效价判断任务, 旨在考察知觉者对不同效价社会和非社会语义信息的加工有何异同。

q4.value:
行为层面：社会语义信息和非社会语义信息具有相同的反应时模式。
大脑神经活动层面：社会语义信息和非社会语义信息具有不同神经活动模式，预期在早期知觉加工阶段大脑可以检测到词汇的社会性及其效价: 负性社会语义信息比其它类型的信息诱发波幅更大的早期成分P1/EPN/N170; 而对非社会语义信息效价的区分要更晚。

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: 本实验的自变量是启动类型(人名 vs. 物名)、启动−靶子在描述内容上的一致性以及靶子词的效价, 将这三个自变量简称为启动、一致性和效价。采用2(启动: 人名 vs. 物名) × 2(一致性: 一致 vs. 冲突) × 2(效价: 正性 vs. 负性)的被试内实验设计, 这样构成8种实验处理。实验1（行为实验） 每种实验条件下有30个试次。因变量是正确率和反应时。实验2（ERP实验） 每种实验条件下有60个试次，ERP成分是主要观测的因变量指标。

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
实验1：采用E-prime 2.0设计实验程序。在正式实验前, 先进行32个试次的练习, 短暂休息后进入正式实验。在正式实验中, 被试共完成240个随机呈现的试次, 每60个试次休息一次。所有试次呈现刺激的顺序如图1所示: 首先呈现注视点“+” (500 ms), 紧接着呈现启动刺激(500 ms), 其后间隔500 ms空屏, 然后呈现靶刺激(1000 ms); 靶刺激之后呈现空屏, 待被试做出反应后随机间隔600~800 ms, 开始下一个试次。要求被试尽准确、尽快判断靶子词的效价: 若为正性, 则按“积极”键; 若为负性, 则按“消极”键。实验前将“积极”、“消极”反应提示标签分别贴在键盘“ E ”和“ I ”键上, 被试间平衡按键左右手。另外, 提醒被试在实验过程中一直注视屏幕中央, 休息时可以放松。练习阶段的所有词汇在正式实验阶段没有出现。
实验2（ERP实验）通过 E-Prime 2.0 呈现刺激, 记录和收集行为数据（程序与实验1完全相同）; 使用 NeuroScan Synamps 2 脑电记录与分析系统采集和分析脑电数据。采用 64 导 Ag/AgCl 电极帽记录头皮62个电极位置的EEG以及水平眼电 (HEOG)和垂直眼电(VEOG), 电极排列按照国际 10-20 标准。水平眼电记录电极放置于两眼外眦外侧 1.5 cm 处, 垂直眼电记录电极放置于左眼框上、下 1 cm 处。以左侧乳突为参考电极, 对侧乳突为记录电极, 前额接地。AC 采样, 采样频率为 500 Hz, 滤波带通为 0.05~100 Hz。头皮电阻小于 5 kΩ。

q13.value:
实验1拟招募大学生被试40人。所有被试均未参与过本研究前期的实验材料收集与评定。
实验2拟招募大学生被试30人。所有被试均未参与过本研究前期的实验材料收集与评定, 且没有参加实验1。所有被试身体健康, 视力或矫正视力正常, 无色弱色盲, 均为右利手。

question.value: 本研究两个实验所操纵的自变量均为启动、一致性和效价。启动有两个水平: 人名 vs. 物名；一致性有两个水平：一致 vs. 不一致；效价有两个水平：正性 vs. 负性

实验1：反应时，正确率
实验2：反应时，正确率，ERP成分的波幅和潜伏期

行为数据：以反应时和正确率为因变量, 进行2(启动: 人名 vs. 物名) × 2(一致性: 一致 vs. 冲突) × 2(效价: 正性 vs. 负性)的重复测量方差分析, 所有因素均为组内变量, 反应时在分析前剔除错误反应的以及超出平均数正负两个标准差的数据(Ratcliff, 1993)。
ERP数据：（1）离线分析。离线分析时将记录到的原始 EEG 数据转换为双侧乳突平均参考; 合并行为数据, 脑电预览后, 剔除 EEG 中由眼动和眨眼引起的眼电伪迹(Gratton, Coles, & Donchin, 1983); EEG 分析时程为 1200 ms, 其中以靶刺激呈现前 200 ms 作为基线; 去除超出± 90 μV的伪迹, 然后叠加平均每个被试在8种条件下正确反应的 EEG (叠加次数均在总trial数的80% 即48 次以上), 最后对叠加平均后的 ERPs 数据采用 FIR 数字滤波器进行 30 Hz (24 dB/oct)的无相移低通数字滤波。 （2）统计分析。基于各个受到实验自变量显著影响的成分的兴趣区(Regions of Interest, ROI) 进行测量统计。对每个成分的ROI平均波幅分别进行2(启动: 人名 vs. 物名) × 2(一致性: 一致 vs. 冲突) × 2(效价: 正性 vs. 负性)的重复测量方差分析。

q22.value:
反应时在分析前剔除错误反应的以及超出平均数正负两个标准差的数据(Ratcliff, 1993)。
ERP数据分析时剔除伪迹过多导致最后叠加平均的Trials数目少于80%的被试。

registration_responses.q3:
近期以图片为实验材料的ERP研究操纵了图片刺激的效价和社会性, 一致证明了图片中信息的社会性和效价的加工存在着交互作用。 描述人的词汇是一类非常重要的、特别的社会语义信息, 且关于人的特质描述往往带有评价性, 亦即具有某种效价。因此, 不论是从理论上还是从研究的生态效度上, 都需要将词汇的效价作为重要的自变量进行考察。然而, 以往以描述人的词汇为实验材料探讨社会语义信息加工特异性的ERP研究, 尚未涉及对词汇效价的操纵(e. g., Wang et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2018; White et al., 2009; 杨亚平 等, 2015)。尽管近期也有研究以描述人的词汇为实验材料且操纵了效价, 但此类研究仅考察了社会语义信息加工的神经活动特征, 缺乏与之对比的非社会语义信息(Zhang et al., 2014; Zhao, Chen, Zhou, & Luo, 2018)。尽管对于ERP实验而言上述研究中所选取的描述人的词汇有限(正性、负性和中性的词汇各6个)且研究结果不完全一致, 但这两项研究提供了大脑在早期知觉阶段就可以检测并区分负性社会语义信息的证据。然而, 同样由于缺乏之对比的非社会语义信息, 这一负性词汇的早期知觉优势是否是社会语义信息所特有的还需进一步验证。总之, 关于不同效价的社会语义信息的加工有何特异性这一问题亟需探讨。
为此, 本研究拟结合行为反应时技术和具有高时间分辨率的ERP技术, 借鉴Mitchell等人(2002)的研究, 操纵了社会语义信息和与之对比的非社会语义信息, 即以描述人的词汇和描述无生命物体的词汇为研究对象, 采用启动范式——以人名和物名为启动刺激, 以描述人的词汇(如: 大度、懒惰)和描述物的词汇(如: 可口、破旧)为靶子刺激。所不同的是, 本研究操纵了词汇的效价并采用靶子词效价判断任务, 旨在考察知觉者对不同效价社会和非社会语义信息的加工有何异同。
registration_responses.q4:
行为层面：社会语义信息和非社会语义信息具有相同的反应时模式。
大脑神经活动层面：社会语义信息和非社会语义信息具有不同神经活动模式，预期在早期知觉加工阶段大脑可以检测到词汇的社会性及其效价: 负性社会语义信息比其它类型的信息诱发波幅更大的早期成分P1/EPN/N170; 而对非社会语义信息效价的区分要更晚。
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13:
实验1拟招募大学生被试40人。所有被试均未参与过本研究前期的实验材料收集与评定。
实验2拟招募大学生被试30人。所有被试均未参与过本研究前期的实验材料收集与评定, 且没有参加实验1。所有被试身体健康, 视力或矫正视力正常, 无色弱色盲, 均为右利手。
registration_responses.q22:
反应时在分析前剔除错误反应的以及超出平均数正负两个标准差的数据(Ratcliff, 1993)。
ERP数据分析时剔除伪迹过多导致最后叠加平均的Trials数目少于80%的被试。
registration_responses.q8.question: 本实验的自变量是启动类型(人名 vs. 物名)、启动−靶子在描述内容上的一致性以及靶子词的效价, 将这三个自变量简称为启动、一致性和效价。采用2(启动: 人名 vs. 物名) × 2(一致性: 一致 vs. 冲突) × 2(效价: 正性 vs. 负性)的被试内实验设计, 这样构成8种实验处理。实验1（行为实验） 每种实验条件下有30个试次。因变量是正确率和反应时。实验2（ERP实验） 每种实验条件下有60个试次，ERP成分是主要观测的因变量指标。
registration_responses.q12.question:
实验1：采用E-prime 2.0设计实验程序。在正式实验前, 先进行32个试次的练习, 短暂休息后进入正式实验。在正式实验中, 被试共完成240个随机呈现的试次, 每60个试次休息一次。所有试次呈现刺激的顺序如图1所示: 首先呈现注视点“+” (500 ms), 紧接着呈现启动刺激(500 ms), 其后间隔500 ms空屏, 然后呈现靶刺激(1000 ms); 靶刺激之后呈现空屏, 待被试做出反应后随机间隔600~800 ms, 开始下一个试次。要求被试尽准确、尽快判断靶子词的效价: 若为正性, 则按“积极”键; 若为负性, 则按“消极”键。实验前将“积极”、“消极”反应提示标签分别贴在键盘“ E ”和“ I ”键上, 被试间平衡按键左右手。另外, 提醒被试在实验过程中一直注视屏幕中央, 休息时可以放松。练习阶段的所有词汇在正式实验阶段没有出现。
实验2（ERP实验）通过 E-Prime 2.0 呈现刺激, 记录和收集行为数据（程序与实验1完全相同）; 使用 NeuroScan Synamps 2 脑电记录与分析系统采集和分析脑电数据。采用 64 导 Ag/AgCl 电极帽记录头皮62个电极位置的EEG以及水平眼电 (HEOG)和垂直眼电(VEOG), 电极排列按照国际 10-20 标准。水平眼电记录电极放置于两眼外眦外侧 1.5 cm 处, 垂直眼电记录电极放置于左眼框上、下 1 cm 处。以左侧乳突为参考电极, 对侧乳突为记录电极, 前额接地。AC 采样, 采样频率为 500 Hz, 滤波带通为 0.05~100 Hz。头皮电阻小于 5 kΩ。
registration_responses.q16.question: 本研究两个实验所操纵的自变量均为启动、一致性和效价。启动有两个水平: 人名 vs. 物名；一致性有两个水平：一致 vs. 不一致；效价有两个水平：正性 vs. 负性
registration_responses.q17.question:
实验1：反应时，正确率
实验2：反应时，正确率，ERP成分的波幅和潜伏期
registration_responses.q19.question:
行为数据：以反应时和正确率为因变量, 进行2(启动: 人名 vs. 物名) × 2(一致性: 一致 vs. 冲突) × 2(效价: 正性 vs. 负性)的重复测量方差分析, 所有因素均为组内变量, 反应时在分析前剔除错误反应的以及超出平均数正负两个标准差的数据(Ratcliff, 1993)。
ERP数据：（1）离线分析。离线分析时将记录到的原始 EEG 数据转换为双侧乳突平均参考; 合并行为数据, 脑电预览后, 剔除 EEG 中由眼动和眨眼引起的眼电伪迹(Gratton, Coles, & Donchin, 1983); EEG 分析时程为 1200 ms, 其中以靶刺激呈现前 200 ms 作为基线; 去除超出± 90 μV的伪迹, 然后叠加平均每个被试在8种条件下正确反应的 EEG (叠加次数均在总trial数的80% 即48 次以上), 最后对叠加平均后的 ERPs 数据采用 FIR 数字滤波器进行 30 Hz (24 dB/oct)的无相移低通数字滤波。 （2）统计分析。基于各个受到实验自变量显著影响的成分的兴趣区(Regions of Interest, ROI) 进行测量统计。对每个成分的ROI平均波幅分别进行2(启动: 人名 vs. 物名) × 2(一致性: 一致 vs. 冲突) × 2(效价: 正性 vs. 负性)的重复测量方差分析。

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Once it’s part of me, it’s also positive

other.value:
As a manipulation check, an RT shape-label matching task (as established by Sui, He, & Humphreys, 2012) will be run to measure self-prioritization of the self- (as opposed to the stranger-) associated shape-label pair. Trials comprising matching shape-label pairs will be subjected to a one-factorial within-participants MANOVA with the factor shape association (self vs. stranger). We expect this analysis to reveal RTs to be significantly faster on self- vs. stranger-associated trials.
Additionally, we will further analyze IAT performance. That is, we will conduct two separate 2 (association: self vs. furniture) × 2 (trial type: compatible vs. incompatible) × 2 (representation type: familiar vs. new) ANOVAs regarding RTs, on the one hand, and error rates, on the other hand.

sample.value: Until there is usable data from at least 72 participants.

analyses.value: We will conduct a 2 (association: self vs. furniture) × 2 (representation type: familiar vs. new) repeated measures ANOVA on compatibility effects. We expect stronger compatibility effects for self-associated than for furniture-associated stimuli, denoting higher valence of the self- than the furniture-associated stimuli. We expect this difference to be reliable both for familiar and new representations (though it might be larger for familiar stimuli than for newly self- vs. furniture-associated stimuli).

outliers.value:
Only data from sessions in which all measures have been completed will be included in the analysis.
The mean error rate and mean RT of each participant will be compared to the sample distribution of the mean error rates and RTs of all participants to identify outliers as described by Tukey (1977). If the data from any participant constitutes an outlier, it will be excluded from the analyses.

dependent.value: Participants will perform a recoding-free variant of the self-esteem implicit association test (IAT; Greenwald & Farnham, 2000), in which Response times (RT) and error rates will be assessed (IAT-RF; Rothermund, Teige-Mocigemba, Gast, & Wentura, 2009). We will compute individual compatibility effects by subtracting each participant’s mean correct RT on compatible trials from that on incompatible trials. These compatibility effects will serve as our main dependent variable; they will be interpreted as implicit measures of valence.

conditions.value: Each participant will perform one of two versions of the IAT-RF. Within the IAT, all participants will categorize self- vs. furniture-associated stimuli. These will either be represented by familiar word stimuli or by newly self- and furniture-associated stimuli (in reference to association rules that participants will familiarize with at the beginning of the experiment). In addition, all participants will be asked to categorize positive and negative word stimuli. That is, the study will comprise a 2 (representation type: familiar vs. new; between-participants) × 2 (association: self vs. furniture, within-participants) × 2 (mapping: compatible vs. incompatible) within-participants design. For the compatible mapping, participants will have to respond to positive/negative and self-/furniture-associated stimuli by pressing the same response key, whereas for the incompatible mapping, they will have to respond to negative/positive and self-/furniture-associated stimuli by pressing the same response key.

hypothesis.value: On an implicit measure, we expect familiar self-associated stimuli to show higher valence than familiar stimuli associated to the category “furniture”. Moreover, we expect newly self-associated stimuli to also show higher valence then newly furniture-associated stimuli.

attributes.title: First-Line Antimetabolites for Steroid-sparing Treatment (FAST) Uveitis Trial Sub-Analysis: Predictive Modeling Project
attributes.description: Assessing potential patient predictors (e.g. gender, level of ocular inflammation) for treatment success in the FAST uveitis trial.

comments.value: Data from the FAST uveitis trial (see: https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2749597) was cleaned and briefly reviewed based on the variables of interest. Steps beyond data cleaning have not taken place yet (i.e. assessing variable correlation, model building).
